title: Budget 2015: Shareholders facing £7bn raid on income from dividends
text:
Investors who earn more than £5,000 a year in dividend income from their investments face higher tax bills from next April 
Wealthy savers face a £7billion tax raid on the income they receive from stock market investments. 
Experts said that basic rate taxpayers, including pensioners who had built up a nest egg during their working lives, would also be affected. 
Investors who earn more than £5,000 a year from the dividends paid by FTSE companies, such as Lloyds, Vodafone and BP, will face higher tax bills from next April under the levy. 
Dermot Callinan, a partner and head of private clients at KPMG, the account-ancy practice, said: "This is clearly a tax rise for affluent investors, who face much higher rates overall, but this won't just apply to the rich. 
"Some of those affected will be pensioners paying basic-rate taxpayers because their earnings are less than £40,000 a year. 
"If more than £5,000 comes from dividends, they will now pay tax on that income." 
Currently, dividends paid to basicrate taxpayers are regarded as taxed already — companies pay a levy within the corporate tax system — so there is no further tax to pay. 
Under the new rules, only the first £5,000 a year of dividend income will remain exempt. 
For dividend income above this allowance, basic-rate taxpayers will pay 7.5 per cent. Higher-rate taxpayers will pay 32.5 per cent, up from 25 per cent currently. Additional rate taxpayers who earn more than £150,000 a year face a charge of 38.1 per cent on the dividend income, up from 30.56 per cent today. 
The Budget document said: "While these rates remain below the main rates of income tax, those who receive significant dividend income - for example due to very large shareholdings or as a result of receiving significant dividends through a closed company - will pay more." 
The dividends paid by companies to shareholders average around 3.5 per cent. So someone who holds more than £140,000 worth of shares is likely to pay increased taxes. 
Calculations published by the Treasury showed the changes will raise £6.76 billion over the next five years.
